<div id="hs_cos_wrapper_module_1523032069834331" class="hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_widget hs_cos_wrapper_type_module widget-type-blog_content" style="" data-hs-cos-general-type="widget" data-hs-cos-type="module">
    <div class="blog-section">
<div class="blog-post-wrapper cell-wrapper">
<div class="blog-section">
<div class="blog-post-wrapper cell-wrapper">
<div class="post-page-content"> 
<div class="hs-featured-image-wrapper">
<a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/price-intelligence-questions-answered" title="" class="hs-featured-image-link">
<img src="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hubfs/Your-Price-Intelligence-Questions-answered-blog-jul-2020-v1.gif" class="hs-featured-image" alt="">
</a>
</div>
<div class="section post-header">
<h1><span id="hs_cos_wrapper_name" class="hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_text" style="" data-hs-cos-general-type="meta_field" data-hs-cos-type="text">Your Price Intelligence Questions Answered</span></h1>
<div class="byline">
<span class="date">
<i class="fa fa-calendar-o"></i>
<a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/price-intelligence-questions-answered">July 28, 2020 </a>
</span>
<span class="author">
<i class="fa fa-user"></i>
<a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/author/himanshi-bhatt">Himanshi Bhatt</a>	
</span>
<span class="custom_listing_comments">
<i class="fa fa-comments-o"></i>
<a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/price-intelligence-questions-answered#comments-listing">0 Comments</a>
</span>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section post-body">
<span id="hs_cos_wrapper_post_body" class="hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_rich_text" style="" data-hs-cos-general-type="meta_field" data-hs-cos-type="rich_text"><h2>What is Price Intelligence?</h2>
<p>Price Intelligence is leveraging web data to make better pricing, marketing, and business decisions. Basically, it is all about making use of the available data to optimize your pricing strategy, making it more competitive, increasing profitability, and ultimately, improving your business performance.</p>
<!--more-->
<p>From competitor monitoring to dynamic pricing and MAP monitoring, web extracted pricing data has endless uses. Brands and e-commerce companies use pricing data to monitor an overall view of the market. Dynamic pricing can be used to make automatic pricing decisions based on competitor’s data combined with internal data so that you always remain profitable. MAP or Minimum Advertising Price monitoring is a technique that uses web extracted data to ensure the resellers and partners are maintaining the pricing according to the company policies.</p>
<p>During our webinar on “<span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://info.scrapinghub.com/fuelling-price-intelligence-with-web-data-extraction-gate" style="color: #990100;">Fuelling Price Intelligence With Web Data Extraction</a></span>” in June 2020, we had a lot of questions related to the processes and challenges of pricing data extraction. We cover a few important questions here:</p>
<h3 style="font-size: 20px; font-weight: bold;"><strong>Q: While monitoring prices, how do you account for promotional codes? How do you automatically apply additional promotions codes that can be applied to the selling price as seen on the listing page?</strong></h3>
<p>A: It varies from website to website, but the general idea is to find the pages where such promotion codes are available and build the logic of looking up code and applying it (clicking a button or sending AJAX request) into your extraction code.</p>
<h3 style="font-size: 20px;"><strong>Q: How do you detect and act on the erroneous pricing that some websites intentionally showcase to confuse price intelligence efforts?</strong></h3>
<p>A: Websites showcase erroneous pricing data when they detect you scraping regularly. This especially happens when you are trying to scale - i.e scrape a lot of products very frequently. Erroneous pricing is not easily recognizable, but comparing the prices or other data fields with previously extracted data and manually checking if there is a big difference in the extracted data can help.</p>
<p>The long-term solution for this would be to be smarter about how you scale and be more thoughtful about the <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://www.scrapinghub.com/crawlera/" style="color: #990100;">proxy solutions</a></span> you use.</p>
<h3 style="font-size: 20px;"><strong>Q: How do you make sure that the data you scrape is accurate?</strong></h3>
<p>A: Scraping accurate data is all about having a reliable quality assurance process. The first step towards this process is to have a well-defined JSON schema. Your QA process needs to be a balanced combination of automated ways of testing the data as well as manual ways. This blog post gives a detailed description of <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/web-data-qa-part-iii-combining-manual-and-automated-techniques-for-holistic-data-validation" style="color: #990100;">data validation techniques</a></span>.</p>
<h3 style="font-size: 20px;"><strong>Q: What are the challenges in scraping prices from sites that are javascript heavy?</strong></h3>
<p>A: For javascript heavy sites, the simplest way would be to inspect the website and see if it uses any hidden APIs that have the data in JSON or other simple formats. This way, you can get the data without executing the javascript.</p>
<p>However, sometimes that may not work. In that case, you will need to execute the javascript using a headless browser like <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://www.scrapinghub.com/splash/" style="color: #990100;">Splash</a></span> or Selenium or Puppeteer. The challenge here is that it will consume more resources making the process more expensive.</p>
<h3 style="font-size: 20px;"><strong>Q: How do you match products across websites?</strong></h3>
<p>A: There are many ways to conduct product matching. The main idea would be to gather as many product-specific parameters as you can about the product that you want to match and then compare those parameters.</p>
<p>Eg: For a TV, the product-specific parameters would be resolution, weight, sound, etc. If in comparison, 90% of the parameters of any two products are the same, there is a high chance that it is the same product across two websites.</p>
<p>You can build models on this concept to identify product duplication.</p>
<h2><span>Price Intelligence Webinar</span></h2>
<p>Want to know more about how you can fuel your price intelligence decisions with web extracted data? Watch this webinar where our Technology Evangelist Attila Toth takes you on a deep dive through the main challenges affecting price intelligence projects from both a business and technical perspective, and more importantly, how you can solve them.</p>
<p><!--HubSpot Call-to-Action Code --><span class="hs-cta-wrapper" id="hs-cta-wrapper-786cfc77-4b78-4430-a3ce-fd5b48227518"><span class="hs-cta-node hs-cta-786cfc77-4b78-4430-a3ce-fd5b48227518" id="hs-cta-786cfc77-4b78-4430-a3ce-fd5b48227518"><!--[if lte IE 8]><div id="hs-cta-ie-element"></div><![endif]--><a href="https://cta-redirect.hubspot.com/cta/redirect/4367560/786cfc77-4b78-4430-a3ce-fd5b48227518" target="_blank"><img class="hs-cta-img" id="hs-cta-img-786cfc77-4b78-4430-a3ce-fd5b48227518" style="border-width:0px;margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px" src="https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/4367560/786cfc77-4b78-4430-a3ce-fd5b48227518.png" alt="Watch Now" align="middle"></a></span><script charset="utf-8" src="/hs/cta/cta/current.js"></script><script type="text/javascript"> hbspt.cta._relativeUrls=true;hbspt.cta.load(4367560, '786cfc77-4b78-4430-a3ce-fd5b48227518', {}); </script></span><!-- end HubSpot Call-to-Action Code --></p>
<p>If you have any more questions or queries on Price Intelligence data extraction, feel free to leave a comment below and we will try our best to answer them.</p>

(function () {
    window.addEventListener('load', function () {
        setTimeout(function () {
            var xhr = new XMLHttpRequest();
            xhr.open('POST', '/_hcms/perf', true /*async*/);
            xhr.setRequestHeader("Content-type", "application/json");
            xhr.onreadystatechange = function () {
                // do nothing.
            };
            var connection = navigator.connection || navigator.mozConnection || navigator.webkitConnection;
            function populateNetworkInfo(name, connection, info) {
                if (name in connection) {
                    info[name] = connection[name];
                }
            }
            var networkInfo = {};
            if (connection) {
                ['type', 'effectiveType', 'downlink', 'rtt'].forEach(function(name) {
                    populateNetworkInfo(name, connection, networkInfo);
                });
            }
            var perfData = {
                url: location.href,
                portal: 4367560,
                content: 32737816533,
                group: -1,
                connection: networkInfo,
                timing: performance.timing
            };
            xhr.send(JSON.stringify(perfData));
        }, 3000);  // Execute this 3 seconds after onload.
    });
})();
</script>

<!-- Save UTM for links to app.scrapinghub.com -->
<script>
function getQueryStrParam(name, url) {
    if (!url) url = window.location.search;
    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
        results = regex.exec(url);
    if (!results) return null;
    if (!results[2]) return '';
    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
}

function storeUrlParam(param_name, url) {
    var hasCookie = getStoredParam(param_name);
    if (hasCookie == "" || hasCookie) return;
    var param = getQueryStrParam(param_name, url) || "";
    Cookies.set(param_name, param, {
        domain: ".scrapinghub.com",
        expires: 90
    })
}

function getStoredParam(param_name) {
    return Cookies.get(param_name, {
        domain: ".scrapinghub.com"
    })
}

function isPlatformLink(dest_url) {
    return (
        dest_url.startsWith("https://app.scrapinghub.com") ||
        dest_url.startsWith("http://app.scrapinghub.com") ||
        dest_url.startsWith("app.scrapinghub.com")
    )
}

jQuery(function ($) {
    $(document).on('click', 'a[cta_dest_link]', function(e) {
        const dest_url = $(e.currentTarget).attr("cta_dest_link");
        if ( dest_url && isPlatformLink(dest_url)) {
            storeUrlParam("utm_campaign", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_activity", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_medium", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_source", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_content", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_primary", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_secondary", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_goal", dest_url);
        }
    }); 
});
</script>

<div id="hs_cos_wrapper_module_1523032069834331" class="hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_widget hs_cos_wrapper_type_module widget-type-blog_content" style="" data-hs-cos-general-type="widget" data-hs-cos-type="module">

<div class="blog-post-wrapper cell-wrapper">
<div class="blog-section">
<div class="blog-post-wrapper cell-wrapper">
<div class="post-page-content"> 
<div class="hs-featured-image-wrapper">
<a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/price-gouging-or-economics-at-work-price-intelligence-to-track-consumer-sentiment" title="" class="hs-featured-image-link">
<img src="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hubfs/Price-Gouging-or-Economics-at-Work---Price-Intelligence-to-Track-Consumer-Sentiment-jun2020-v1.png" class="hs-featured-image" alt="">
</a>
</div>
<div class="section post-header">
<h1><span id="hs_cos_wrapper_name" class="hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_text" style="" data-hs-cos-general-type="meta_field" data-hs-cos-type="text">Price Gouging or Economics at Work: Price Intelligence to Track Consumer Sentiment</span></h1>
<div class="byline">
<span class="date">
<i class="fa fa-calendar-o"></i>
<a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/price-gouging-or-economics-at-work-price-intelligence-to-track-consumer-sentiment">June 11, 2020 </a>
</span>
<span class="author">
<i class="fa fa-user"></i>
<a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/author/robert-cosgrave">Robert Cosgrave</a>	
</span>
<span class="custom_listing_comments">
<i class="fa fa-comments-o"></i>
<a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/price-gouging-or-economics-at-work-price-intelligence-to-track-consumer-sentiment#comments-listing">0 Comments</a>
</span>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section post-body">
<span id="hs_cos_wrapper_post_body" class="hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_rich_text" style="" data-hs-cos-general-type="meta_field" data-hs-cos-type="rich_text"><p>As the COVID-19 pandemic took hold, we at Scrapinghub began to wonder how it would impact on the data we crawl, and whether that data could tell us something useful about the pandemic and its impact.</p>
<!--more-->
<p>Retail price intelligence is one of our key areas of interest. On a daily basis, <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="/price-intelligence-web-scraping-at-scale-100-billion-products" rel="noopener" target="_blank" style="color: #990100;">we crawl thousands of eCommerce sites</a></span> for price and stock level information. What insights might be hidden in that data?</p>
<p>To explore this, we identified a basket of goods related to pandemic preparedness (eg Face Masks, medications, etc) and began to track the number of individual items available online in this set, and the average item price over time.</p>
<div><img src="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hubfs/Face%20Mask%20Index%20Covid%20Pricing.png" alt=""></div>
<p>In the first chart, you can see the overall price (in blue), and the number of individual items (SKU’s, in retail parlance, in red) over time for a collection of US data sources. You can see there is a lot of variation in the number of items on supply as new vendors enter the market with basic items. As you might expect, the price often moves in the opposite direction, as in the dip around April 5th. Basic economics works, but the average price doesn’t drop away as strongly as you might expect. Underlying demand is clearly strong. Note that we aren’t looking at stock levels here, just the range of items in stock and available for purchase. Variation in the number of items available could be due to opportunistic vendors entering the market, or rebranding routine supplies with COVID-19 related keywords.</p>
<p>The strength of the underlying demand is such that the overall average price on the basket increased over 40% from March 29th (when we began to track the series) onwards over two months to May 28th. COVID-19 case counts in the US began to lift off in Mid-March, and with <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://www.scrapinghub.com/covid-19-map" rel="noopener" target="_blank" style="color: #990100;">media coverage</a></span> leading that we would expect the ‘normal’ basket price had already risen considerably from its pre-COVID-19 base when we began to track the data.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><img src="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/change-in-cost%20(1).png?width=250&name=change-in-cost%20(1).png" alt="change-in-cost (1)" width="250" style="background-color: transparent; width: 250px; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; float: right;" srcset="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/change-in-cost%20(1).png?width=125&name=change-in-cost%20(1).png 125w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/change-in-cost%20(1).png?width=250&name=change-in-cost%20(1).png 250w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/change-in-cost%20(1).png?width=375&name=change-in-cost%20(1).png 375w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/change-in-cost%20(1).png?width=500&name=change-in-cost%20(1).png 500w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/change-in-cost%20(1).png?width=625&name=change-in-cost%20(1).png 625w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/change-in-cost%20(1).png?width=750&name=change-in-cost%20(1).png 750w" sizes="(max-width: 250px) 100vw, 250px"></p>
<script src="//my.visme.co/visme-embed.js"></script>
<div class="visme_d" data-url="q6jxnkwq-price-intelligence-to-track-consumer-sentiment-map-v2" data-w="800" data-h="500" data-domain="my"> </div>
<p>The interactive map shows the % increase is the average item cost between 1st April and 1st June 2020. You can see that even in a homogeneous market like the US, there is considerable state by state variation in the amount of price increases, with prices more than doubling in some states (Alabama, Wyoming) but showing very modest increases in others (Minnesota). The increases do not seem to correlate with actual observed COVID-19 case levels.</p>
<div><img src="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hubfs/Face%20Mask%20Index%20Covid%20Pricing-1.png" alt=""></div>
<p>The second chart shows the price, overall, and 3 US states, for comparison. You can see the price ‘wobbles’ quite a lot, often with different states not quite in sync. We expected to see lower prices in states with less active cases, but that doesn’t seem to be the case at all, as the fluid US internal market smooths out price variation within a few days, and thus no systematic variation in price.</p>
<p>In late May, something peculiar happened, causing the base price to shoot right up. It’s early to tell, but it appears that the number of items available fell away quite quickly in recent days, with items at lower price points becoming simply unavailable. Thus the average item price shot up to nearly $70 as only high priced items were left in stock. We observe this effect varied regionally, with some states, like New York, having little or no impact, and others showing a price spike without much reduction in supply. We hypothesize this may be due to the recent protests and civil disorder in the US affecting supply chains in interesting ways taking certain goods out of supply in certain regions for a few days and triggering a short price shock.</p>
<p>This reminds us how retail price intelligence data, combined with stock level data and delivery wait times, can give a deep insight into supply chain vulnerabilities, if you know the right questions to ask. Price Intelligence data can be used for purposes not directly connected to simply setting competitive pricing. Economists tell us price is always a signal, and our data is rich in these signals if we know where to look for them, and can interpret them correctly.</p>
<p>If you are interested in extracting COVID-19 related data for research purposes, we can offer our <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://www.scrapinghub.com/covid-19-data" style="color: #990100;" rel="noopener" target="_blank">services for free through our CSR program</a></span>.</p>
<p>If you are interested in <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://www.scrapinghub.com/price-intelligence-data" style="color: #990100;" rel="noopener" target="_blank">price intelligence data</a></span> and what data we could provide to help inform your business decisions, <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://info.scrapinghub.com/sample-pricing-data" style="color: #990100;" rel="noopener" target="_blank">download sample data</a> or <a href="https://www.scrapinghub.com/data-services" style="color: #990100;">get in touch with us</a></span>.</p></span>

(function () {
    window.addEventListener('load', function () {
        setTimeout(function () {
            var xhr = new XMLHttpRequest();
            xhr.open('POST', '/_hcms/perf', true /*async*/);
            xhr.setRequestHeader("Content-type", "application/json");
            xhr.onreadystatechange = function () {
                // do nothing.
            };
            var connection = navigator.connection || navigator.mozConnection || navigator.webkitConnection;
            function populateNetworkInfo(name, connection, info) {
                if (name in connection) {
                    info[name] = connection[name];
                }
            }
            var networkInfo = {};
            if (connection) {
                ['type', 'effectiveType', 'downlink', 'rtt'].forEach(function(name) {
                    populateNetworkInfo(name, connection, networkInfo);
                });
            }
            var perfData = {
                url: location.href,
                portal: 4367560,
                content: 30534572473,
                group: -1,
                connection: networkInfo,
                timing: performance.timing
            };
            xhr.send(JSON.stringify(perfData));
        }, 3000);  // Execute this 3 seconds after onload.
    });
})();
</script>

<!-- Save UTM for links to app.scrapinghub.com -->
<script>
function getQueryStrParam(name, url) {
    if (!url) url = window.location.search;
    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
        results = regex.exec(url);
    if (!results) return null;
    if (!results[2]) return '';
    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
}

function storeUrlParam(param_name, url) {
    var hasCookie = getStoredParam(param_name);
    if (hasCookie == "" || hasCookie) return;
    var param = getQueryStrParam(param_name, url) || "";
    Cookies.set(param_name, param, {
        domain: ".scrapinghub.com",
        expires: 90
    })
}

function getStoredParam(param_name) {
    return Cookies.get(param_name, {
        domain: ".scrapinghub.com"
    })
}

function isPlatformLink(dest_url) {
    return (
        dest_url.startsWith("https://app.scrapinghub.com") ||
        dest_url.startsWith("http://app.scrapinghub.com") ||
        dest_url.startsWith("app.scrapinghub.com")
    )
}

jQuery(function ($) {
    $(document).on('click', 'a[cta_dest_link]', function(e) {
        const dest_url = $(e.currentTarget).attr("cta_dest_link");
        if ( dest_url && isPlatformLink(dest_url)) {
            storeUrlParam("utm_campaign", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_activity", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_medium", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_source", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_content", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_primary", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_secondary", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_goal", dest_url);
        }
    }); 
});
</script>

<style media="screen" type="text/css">
/* PrismJS 1.15.0
https://prismjs.com/download.html#themes=prism&languages=markup+css+clike+javascript+c+cpp+docker+erlang+git+json+latex+markdown+python+yaml */
/**
 * prism.js default theme for JavaScript, CSS and HTML
 * Based on dabblet (http://dabblet.com)
 * @author Lea Verou
 */

code[class*="language-"],
pre[class*="language-"] {
	color: black;
	background: none;
	text-shadow: 0 1px white;
	font-family: Consolas, Monaco, 'Andale Mono', 'Ubuntu Mono', monospace;
	text-align: left;
	white-space: pre;
	word-spacing: normal;
	word-break: normal;
	word-wrap: normal;
	line-height: 1.5;

	-moz-tab-size: 4;
	-o-tab-size: 4;
	tab-size: 4;

	-webkit-hyphens: none;
	-moz-hyphens: none;
	-ms-hyphens: none;
	hyphens: none;
}

pre[class*="language-"]::-moz-selection, pre[class*="language-"] ::-moz-selection,
code[class*="language-"]::-moz-selection, code[class*="language-"] ::-moz-selection {
	text-shadow: none;
	background: #b3d4fc;
}

pre[class*="language-"]::selection, pre[class*="language-"] ::selection,
code[class*="language-"]::selection, code[class*="language-"] ::selection {
	text-shadow: none;
	background: #b3d4fc;
}

@media print {
	code[class*="language-"],
	pre[class*="language-"] {
		text-shadow: none;
	}
}

/* Code blocks */
pre[class*="language-"] {
	padding: 1em;
	margin: .5em 0;
	overflow: auto;
}

:not(pre) > code[class*="language-"],
pre[class*="language-"] {
	background: #f5f2f0;
}

/* Inline code */
:not(pre) > code[class*="language-"] {
	padding: .1em;
	border-radius: .3em;
	white-space: normal;
}

.token.comment,
.token.prolog,
.token.doctype,
.token.cdata {
	color: slategray;
}

.token.punctuation {
	color: #999;
}

.namespace {
	opacity: .7;
}

.token.property,
.token.tag,
.token.boolean,
.token.number,
.token.constant,
.token.symbol,
.token.deleted {
	color: #905;
}

.token.selector,
.token.attr-name,
.token.string,
.token.char,
.token.builtin,
.token.inserted {
	color: #690;
}

.token.operator,
.token.entity,
.token.url,
.language-css .token.string,
.style .token.string {
	color: #9a6e3a;
	background: hsla(0, 0%, 100%, .5);
}

.token.atrule,
.token.attr-value,
.token.keyword {
	color: #07a;
}

.token.function,
.token.class-name {
	color: #DD4A68;
}

.token.regex,
.token.important,
.token.variable {
	color: #e90;
}

.token.important,
.token.bold {
	font-weight: bold;
}
.token.italic {
	font-style: italic;
}

.token.entity {
	cursor: help;
}

/* custom styling */
table {
  width: 100%;
  border-collapse: collapse;
}
th, td {
  padding: 0.7em;
}
table, th, td {
  border: 1px solid #ddd;
}
tbody tr:nth-child(odd) {
  background: #eee;
}
  
h2 {
  font-size: 30px;
}
h3 {
  font-size: 24px;
}
  
.post-header h2 a{
  font-size: 40px;
  text-align: center;
  }
</style>

<div id="hs_cos_wrapper_module_1523032069834331" class="hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_widget hs_cos_wrapper_type_module widget-type-blog_content" style="" data-hs-cos-general-type="widget" data-hs-cos-type="module">

<div class="hs-featured-image-wrapper">
<a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/news-api-blog-importance-of-article-quality" title="" class="hs-featured-image-link">

<div class="section post-header">
<h1><span id="hs_cos_wrapper_name" class="hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_text" style="" data-hs-cos-general-type="meta_field" data-hs-cos-type="text">Extracting Article & News Data: The Importance of Data Quality</span></h1>
<div class="byline">
<span class="date">
<i class="fa fa-calendar-o"></i>
<a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/news-api-blog-importance-of-article-quality">June 23, 2020 </a>
</span>
<span class="author">
<i class="fa fa-user"></i>
<a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/author/attila-tóth">Attila Tóth</a>	
</span>
<span class="custom_listing_comments">
<i class="fa fa-comments-o"></i>
<a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/news-api-blog-importance-of-article-quality#comments-listing">0 Comments</a>
</span>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section post-body">
<span id="hs_cos_wrapper_post_body" class="hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_rich_text" style="" data-hs-cos-general-type="meta_field" data-hs-cos-type="rich_text"><p>Article and news data extraction is becoming increasingly popular and widely used by companies. Data quality plays a vital role in making sure these projects succeed. If the quality of the extracted articles is not good enough, your whole business could be at risk, especially if it depends on the constant flow of high quality article data.</p>
<p><!--more--><span style="background-color: transparent;">Data quality enables your business to move data across your organization and transform it into something valuable for your users or customers. With insufficient or inconsistent data quality, your customers might reevaluate using your product or service, as </span><span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/retail/our-insights/the-three-cs-of-customer-satisfaction-consistency-consistency-consistency" style="background-color: transparent; color: #990100;">consistency is something businesses need</a></span><span style="background-color: transparent;"> to acquire and retain customers.</span></p>
<p><span style="background-color: transparent;"></span><a href="https://www.salesforce.com/research/customer-expectations/" style="background-color: transparent;"><span style="color: #990100;">Customers expect</span> </a><span style="background-color: transparent;">to receive high quality services. If your service depends on article data, it means that article extraction directly influences the quality of service your customers get. If you don’t have high extraction quality, your customers won’t get high quality service, which might make them look for another solution.</span></p>
<p><!--HubSpot Call-to-Action Code --><span class="hs-cta-wrapper" id="hs-cta-wrapper-bb001c8c-26f0-4556-a2b0-e1678cb112b4"><span class="hs-cta-node hs-cta-bb001c8c-26f0-4556-a2b0-e1678cb112b4" id="hs-cta-bb001c8c-26f0-4556-a2b0-e1678cb112b4"><!--[if lte IE 8]><div id="hs-cta-ie-element"></div><![endif]--><a href="https://cta-redirect.hubspot.com/cta/redirect/4367560/bb001c8c-26f0-4556-a2b0-e1678cb112b4" target="_blank"><img class="hs-cta-img" id="hs-cta-img-bb001c8c-26f0-4556-a2b0-e1678cb112b4" style="border-width:0px;margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px" src="https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/4367560/bb001c8c-26f0-4556-a2b0-e1678cb112b4.png" alt="In-depth Analysis: Article Extraction Quality" align="middle"></a></span><script charset="utf-8" src="/hs/cta/cta/current.js"></script><script type="text/javascript"> hbspt.cta._relativeUrls=true;hbspt.cta.load(4367560, 'bb001c8c-26f0-4556-a2b0-e1678cb112b4', {}); </script></span><!-- end HubSpot Call-to-Action Code --></p>
<h2>Importance of article extraction quality</h2>
<p>When it comes to web data extraction, data quality is always a key factor. Without high data quality, organizations face increased costs (<span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://www.gartner.com/smarterwithgartner/how-to-stop-data-quality-undermining-your-business/" rel="noopener" target="_blank" style="color: #990100;">$15 million on average per annum according to Gartner</a></span>) let alone having their competitive standing undermined. <span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: #000000;"> </span></p>
<p>If you’re looking for an article extraction solution, your top priority should be data quality. You need to know which service or library provides the best article data quality. You need to learn what metrics are important when you <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://www.itpro.co.uk/business-intelligence-bi/29773/how-to-measure-data-quality" style="color: #990100;">measure data quality</a></span>. But also - moving further from general data quality - what measures are important in article extraction and article body extraction quality.</p>
<p>Article body extraction quality is crucial if your business depends on this kind of data. If you’re developing a product or software that needs structured article/news data constantly, you need to make sure you choose a solution which can prove they provide the best quality on the market.</p>
<h2>Why companies need article extraction</h2>
<p>There are many use cases for article extraction. But one thing is common in each of them: extracting articles from the web gives you a competitive advantage that many companies fail to recognize yet. Web extracted articles and news can make you</p>
<ol>
<li>A smarter decision maker, because you have more information in your hands.</li>
<li>react quicker <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://www.inc.com/adam-fridman/4-reasons-speed-is-everything-in-business.html" style="color: #990100;">when speed matters</a></span>, because you get data close to real-time.</li>
<li>more knowledgeable of your competitors, without lifting a finger.</li>
<li>deliver world-class solutions, backed by high quality data.</li>
</ol>
<p>If you want any of these skills in your arsenal, your top priority should be to choose a solution that has the best article extraction quality on the market.</p>
<h3 style="font-weight: bold;">Brand monitoring, mentions and sentiment analysis</h3>
<p>If you have products sold online, there’s probably a lot of discussion around them as well. <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://www.spectoos.com/5-real-motivations-behind-people-write-customer-reviews/" style="color: #990100;">People love sharing</a></span> their good or bad experiences of a product they bought. These mentions can decide whether future customers buy from you or they choose another brand’s product. Monitoring your brand online and fueling mentions into your business intelligence can improve the way you market, promote and present your products online. It can also show you why people are buying (or not buying) your products.</p>
<h3 style="font-weight: bold;">Competitive intelligence, product launches, mergers and acquisitions</h3>
<p>In today’s competitive market, every piece of additional information about your competitors and their activities is valuable. <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://smallbiztrends.com/2020/01/competitive-intelligence-statistics.html" style="color: #990100;">94% of businesses</a></span> invest in competitive intelligence. It’s not enough to know your product and customers, you also need to follow your market and your competitors. What they are doing, what they are up to. Fortunately, there is one thing that still has the power to <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://hbr.org/2020/01/when-data-creates-competitive-advantage" style="color: #990100;">give you an advantage</a></span>: data. Either you’re an investor or just trying to keep track of your competitors, web article extraction can work wonders delivering competitive intelligence at scale.</p>
<h3 style="font-weight: bold;">Generating dataset to train machine learning models for NLP</h3>
<p>Machine learning models depend on data. The more the better. Luckily, the web offers endless amounts of data. But it’s not just volume that matters. Without high quality data your algorithm is<span style="color: #990100;"> <a href="https://blog.syncsort.com/2019/04/data-quality/data-quality-impact-machine-learning/" style="color: #990100;">useless</a></span>. Bad data quality can cause mistaken analytics, poor decision making and unreliable predictions. Web data is often incomplete, inconsistent or inaccurate. And this can be a<span style="color: #990100;"> <a href="https://towardsdatascience.com/what-to-do-when-bad-data-thwarts-machine-learning-success-fb82249aae8b" style="color: #990100;">huge risk</a></span> for your ML project.</p>
<h3 style="font-weight: bold;">Media personalization, summarization, topic extraction, curation</h3>
<p>Nowadays people publish<span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://www.domo.com/learn/data-never-sleeps-5?aid=ogsm072517_1" style="color: #990100;"> 2.5 quintillion bytes of data</a></span> everyday on the web. But not all news is relevant for everyone. That’s why we see more and more applications and websites that specialize in <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://www.digitaltrends.com/mobile/best-news-apps/" style="color: #990100;">curating and summarizing content</a></span> for readers, based on their interests. Time is a valuable asset for everybody. Using these article extraction based solutions, people can only spend time on news that actually matters for them.</p>
<h3 style="font-weight: bold;">Business verification and investigation (KYC, KYB)</h3>
<p>Whether you are providing <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Know_your_customer" style="color: #990100;">KYC </a></span>(Know-Your-Customer) or KYB (Know-Your-Business) services, or just want to verify a business before engaging in a partnership, getting access in near real-time to related news and articles is important.</p>
<p><span style="color: #444444;">With reliable news data organisation can screen third party's online presence for adverse media coverage, perform more thorough counter-party risk intelligence investigations, and decide based on data-driven insights whether a prospective business partner is genuine, or if there are inherent risks involved in developing or maintaining a business relationship with them. </span></p>
<h3 style="font-weight: bold;">Developing a quantitative model for stock selection</h3>
<p>News has always played a significant role within the financial market, but more so with the emergence of <span style="color: #990100;">q<a href="https://www.investopedia.com/ask/answers/155.asp" rel="noopener" target="_blank" style="color: #990100;">uantitative or systematic trading</a></span>. Economic reports, financial reports or global events can immediately affect the stock market. Thus, in order to make better investing decisions, getting access to articles and news data is essential. With a constant flow of news data, you can improve your quantitative stock selection model.</p>
<h2>Want to learn more about article extraction quality?</h2>
<p>We are sharing a deep study comparing article body extraction quality provided by commercial services and open source libraries. We evaluated the quality of article body extraction for Scrapinghub AutoExtract News API and many other commercial services and open source libraries. If you’re interested to learn more about article extraction quality and want to see the comparison of different services, you can <span style="color: #444444;">download the whitepaper</span>!</p>

<div>
  
<h3>
  Crawl web data at scale without Bottlenecks or slowdowns.

            function populateNetworkInfo(name, connection, info) {
                if (name in connection) {
                    info[name] = connection[name];

            var networkInfo = {};

})();

<!-- Save UTM for links to app.scrapinghub.com -->
<script>
function getQueryStrParam(name, url) {
    if (!url) url = window.location.search;
    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
        results = regex.exec(url);
    if (!results) return null;
    if (!results[2]) return '';
    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
}

function storeUrlParam(param_name, url) {
    var hasCookie = getStoredParam(param_name);
    if (hasCookie == "" || hasCookie) return;
    var param = getQueryStrParam(param_name, url) || "";
    Cookies.set(param_name, param, {
        domain: ".scrapinghub.com",
        expires: 90
    })
}

function getStoredParam(param_name) {
    return Cookies.get(param_name, {
        domain: ".scrapinghub.com"
    })
}

function isPlatformLink(dest_url) {
    return (
        dest_url.startsWith("https://app.scrapinghub.com") ||
        dest_url.startsWith("http://app.scrapinghub.com") ||
        dest_url.startsWith("app.scrapinghub.com")
    )
}

jQuery(function ($) {
    $(document).on('click', 'a[cta_dest_link]', function(e) {
        const dest_url = $(e.currentTarget).attr("cta_dest_link");
        if ( dest_url && isPlatformLink(dest_url)) {
            storeUrlParam("utm_campaign", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_activity", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_medium", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_source", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_content", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_primary", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_secondary", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_goal", dest_url);
        }
    }); 
});
</script>
<!-- END save UTM tags -->

THE SCRAPINGHUB BLOG

Turn Web Content Into Useful Data

Browsed by
Author: Chira Mircea

Web Scraping Basics: A Developer’s Guide To Reliably Extract Data

July 07, 2020 Chira Mircea 0 Comment

The web is complex and constantly changing. It is one of the reasons why web data extraction can be difficult, especially in the long term. It’s necessary to understand how a website works really well, before you try to extract data. Luckily, there are lots of inspection and code tools available for this and in this article we will show you some of our favorites.

Read More

Keep up to date with web scraping and data tips...

/* PrismJS 1.15.0
https://prismjs.com/download.html#themes=prism&languages=markup+css+clike+javascript+c+cpp+docker+erlang+git+json+latex+markdown+python+yaml */
/**
 * prism.js default theme for JavaScript, CSS and HTML
 * Based on dabblet (http://dabblet.com)
 * @author Lea Verou
 */

code[class*="language-"],
pre[class*="language-"] {
	color: black;
	background: none;
	text-shadow: 0 1px white;
	font-family: Consolas, Monaco, 'Andale Mono', 'Ubuntu Mono', monospace;
	text-align: left;
	white-space: pre;
	word-spacing: normal;
	word-break: normal;
	word-wrap: normal;
	line-height: 1.5;

	-moz-tab-size: 4;
	-o-tab-size: 4;
	tab-size: 4;

	-webkit-hyphens: none;
	-moz-hyphens: none;
	-ms-hyphens: none;
	hyphens: none;
}

pre[class*="language-"]::-moz-selection, pre[class*="language-"] ::-moz-selection,
code[class*="language-"]::-moz-selection, code[class*="language-"] ::-moz-selection {
	text-shadow: none;
	background: #b3d4fc;
}

pre[class*="language-"]::selection, pre[class*="language-"] ::selection,
code[class*="language-"]::selection, code[class*="language-"] ::selection {
	text-shadow: none;
	background: #b3d4fc;
}

@media print {
	code[class*="language-"],
	pre[class*="language-"] {
		text-shadow: none;
	}
}

/* Code blocks */
pre[class*="language-"] {
	padding: 1em;
	margin: .5em 0;
	overflow: auto;
}

:not(pre) > code[class*="language-"],
pre[class*="language-"] {
	background: #f5f2f0;
}

/* Inline code */
:not(pre) > code[class*="language-"] {
	padding: .1em;
	border-radius: .3em;
	white-space: normal;
}

.token.comment,
.token.prolog,
.token.doctype,
.token.cdata {
	color: slategray;
}

.token.punctuation {
	color: #999;
}

.namespace {
	opacity: .7;
}

.token.property,
.token.tag,
.token.boolean,
.token.number,
.token.constant,
.token.symbol,
.token.deleted {
	color: #905;
}

.token.selector,
.token.attr-name,
.token.string,
.token.char,
.token.builtin,
.token.inserted {
	color: #690;
}

.token.operator,
.token.entity,
.token.url,
.language-css .token.string,
.style .token.string {
	color: #9a6e3a;
	background: hsla(0, 0%, 100%, .5);
}

.token.atrule,
.token.attr-value,
.token.keyword {
	color: #07a;
}

.token.function,
.token.class-name {
	color: #DD4A68;
}

.token.regex,
.token.important,
.token.variable {
	color: #e90;
}

.token.important,
.token.bold {
	font-weight: bold;
}
.token.italic {
	font-style: italic;
}

.token.entity {
	cursor: help;
}

/* custom styling */
table {
  width: 100%;
  border-collapse: collapse;
}
th, td {
  padding: 0.7em;
}
table, th, td {
  border: 1px solid #ddd;
}
tbody tr:nth-child(odd) {
  background: #eee;
}
  
h2 {
  font-size: 30px;
}
h3 {
  font-size: 24px;
}
  
.post-header h2 a{
  font-size: 40px;
  text-align: center;
  }
</style>

                <div class="section post-header">
                  <h1><span id="hs_cos_wrapper_name" class="hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_text" style="" data-hs-cos-general-type="meta_field" data-hs-cos-type="text">Web Scraping Basics: A Developer’s Guide To Reliably Extract Data</span></h1>
                  <div class="byline">
                    <span class="date">
                      <i class="fa fa-calendar-o"></i>
                      <a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/web-scraping-basics-tools">July 07, 2020 </a>
                    </span>
                    <span class="author">
                      <i class="fa fa-user"></i>
                      <a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/author/chira-mircea">Chira Mircea</a>	
                    </span>
                    <span class="custom_listing_comments">
                      <i class="fa fa-comments-o"></i>
                      
                      
                      <a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/web-scraping-basics-tools#comments-listing">0 Comments</a>
                    </span>
                  </div>
             </div>
                
                <div class="section post-body">
                  <span id="hs_cos_wrapper_post_body" class="hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_rich_text" style="" data-hs-cos-general-type="meta_field" data-hs-cos-type="rich_text"><p>The web is complex and constantly changing. It is one of the reasons why web data extraction can be difficult, especially in the long term. It’s necessary to understand how a website works really well, before you try to extract data. Luckily, there are lots of inspection and code tools available for this and in this article we will show you some of our favorites.</p>
<!--more-->
<p><span style="background-color: transparent;">These tools can be used for free and are available for all major platforms.</span></p>
<p><span style="color: #37474f; font-size: 30px; font-weight: 600; letter-spacing: -1px; text-align: left; word-spacing: -1px; background-color: transparent;">Developer tools</span></p>
<p>All major browsers come packed with a set of development tools. Although these have been built with the goal of building websites in mind, they can also be used to analyze web pages and traffic. These are some pretty powerful tools for working with websites.</p>
<p>For Google Chrome, these developer tools can be accessed from any page by right-clicking then choosing 'Inspect' or using the shortcut 'CTRL + shift + I' (or '⌘ + Option + I' on macs).</p>
<p>You can use these tools to perform some basic operations:</p>
<h3>Checking the page source</h3>
<p>Most web pages contain a lot of javascript that needs to be executed before you can see the final output. But you can see how the initial request looks before all of this by checking the page source. To do that you can right-click and then click on 'View page source' or use the shortcuts:</p>
<p>Press CTRL + U (⌘ + Option + U) to view source<br>Press CTRL + F (⌘ + Option + F) to search<br><br><em>Tip: You should always check the page source as it can contain the same information in more reliable places. For example, you may find the title of a product you're scraping in a meta tag that is not displayed in the rendered output.</em></p>
<div><img src="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-27-AM.png?width=773&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-27-AM.png" alt="" style="width: 773px;" width="773" srcset="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-27-AM.png?width=387&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-27-AM.png 387w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-27-AM.png?width=773&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-27-AM.png 773w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-27-AM.png?width=1160&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-27-AM.png 1160w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-27-AM.png?width=1546&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-27-AM.png 1546w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-27-AM.png?width=1933&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-27-AM.png 1933w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-27-AM.png?width=2319&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-27-AM.png 2319w" sizes="(max-width: 773px) 100vw, 773px"></div>
<h3>Inspecting traffic</h3>
<p>Sometimes the information you're looking for is not loaded with the first request. Or perhaps there is an API call that loads the data you need. In order to “catch” these calls, you'll want to see what requests are needed to load a certain page. You can find out this and more in the 'Network' tab. This is what it looks like:</p>
<div><img src="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-74-AM.png" alt=""></div>
<div> </div>
<div>You can filter requests by their url in the 'Filter' input box:</div>
<div> </div>
<div><img src="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-1.png?width=217&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-1.png" alt="" style="width: 217px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;" width="217" srcset="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-1.png?width=109&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-1.png 109w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-1.png?width=217&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-1.png 217w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-1.png?width=326&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-1.png 326w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-1.png?width=434&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-1.png 434w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-1.png?width=543&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-1.png 543w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-1.png?width=651&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-1.png 651w" sizes="(max-width: 217px) 100vw, 217px"></div>
<div> </div>
<div>You can also filter requests by type, for example, you can filter for XHR requests. These are endpoints from where js can request resources. There are many other types as well.</div>
<div> </div>
<div><img src="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea.png?width=416&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea.png" alt="" style="width: 416px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;" width="416" srcset="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea.png?width=208&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea.png 208w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea.png?width=416&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea.png 416w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea.png?width=624&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea.png 624w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea.png?width=832&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea.png 832w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea.png?width=1040&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea.png 1040w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea.png?width=1248&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea.png 1248w" sizes="(max-width: 416px) 100vw, 416px"></div>
<div> </div>
<div>You can also clear the request list by pressing this button, this will not reload the page.</div>
<div> </div>
<div><img src="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-4.png?width=255&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-4.png" alt="" style="width: 255px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;" width="255" srcset="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-4.png?width=128&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-4.png 128w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-4.png?width=255&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-4.png 255w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-4.png?width=383&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-4.png 383w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-4.png?width=510&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-4.png 510w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-4.png?width=638&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-4.png 638w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-4.png?width=765&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-4.png 765w" sizes="(max-width: 255px) 100vw, 255px"></div>
<div> </div>
<h3>Inspecting requests</h3>
<p>Of course, you'll also need to know the details on individual requests. If you click on any of these you'll be able to see a lot more information such as request and response headers, cookies and the payload used when sending POST requests for example.</p>
<p>Let's take a look at one of the requests needed to load the main page of google.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><img src="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-2.png" alt=""></p>
<p>This is the preview of a request, you can see here information such as the status code, url and type. Clicking on this request we can get even more information:</p>
<div><img src="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-40-09-AM.png?width=600&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-40-09-AM.png" alt="" style="width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;" width="600" srcset="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-40-09-AM.png?width=300&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-40-09-AM.png 300w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-40-09-AM.png?width=600&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-40-09-AM.png 600w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-40-09-AM.png?width=900&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-40-09-AM.png 900w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-40-09-AM.png?width=1200&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-40-09-AM.png 1200w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-40-09-AM.png?width=1500&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-40-09-AM.png 1500w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-40-09-AM.png?width=1800&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-40-09-AM.png 1800w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px"></div>
<div> </div>
<div>In the new dialog that popped up, you can see the request and response headers. Also, in the 'Preview' and 'Response' tabs you can see the response received for this particular request.</div>
<p>Both are very useful for debugging since for JSON API calls, the 'Preview' tab will display an easy to navigate structure while for HTML responses you can view the rendered response or simply the source HTML in the 'Response' tab. The search feature also comes handy sometimes.</p>
<p>You can clear your browser cookies and cache from the 'Network' tab, a feature often used when testing how fast a page loads for example, also can be used to clear things such as session ids. Right-click on any request to open this dialog box:</p>
<div><img src="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-3.png?width=250&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-3.png" alt="" style="width: 250px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;" width="250" srcset="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-3.png?width=125&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-3.png 125w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-3.png?width=250&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-3.png 250w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-3.png?width=375&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-3.png 375w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-3.png?width=500&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-3.png 500w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-3.png?width=625&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-3.png 625w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-3.png?width=750&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-3.png 750w" sizes="(max-width: 250px) 100vw, 250px"></div>
<div> </div>
<div>You can also export a request to a curl command by right-clicking on it in this panel then go to copy then Copy as curl. Again, right-click on the request you want and then on the 'Copy' section:</div>
<div> </div>
<div><img src="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-51-AM.png?width=400&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-51-AM.png" alt="" style="width: 400px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;" width="400" srcset="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-51-AM.png?width=200&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-51-AM.png 200w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-51-AM.png?width=400&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-51-AM.png 400w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-51-AM.png?width=600&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-51-AM.png 600w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-51-AM.png?width=800&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-51-AM.png 800w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-51-AM.png?width=1000&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-51-AM.png 1000w, https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hs-fs/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-51-AM.png?width=1200&name=scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-51-AM.png 1200w" sizes="(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px"></div>
<h3> </h3>
<h3>Extensions</h3>
<p>There are a lot of functionalities you can add for the browser using a few extensions. Our favorites for web scraping::</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/dont-fingerprint-me/nhbedikkbkakbjipijipejfojanppbfg" style="color: #990100;">DFPM</a></span> - don't fingerprint me, an extension that checks how the website identifies your device, useful when you're getting blocked, and a great resource for learning</li>
<li><span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/xpath-helper/hgimnogjllphhhkhlmebbmlgjoejdpjl" style="color: #990100;">XPath helper</a></span> - a bit more visual and assisted XPath tool, you can see the exact output of an XPath directly in your browser. Be mindful though as this may not be the same as what you will get in you spider</li>
<li>VPN extensions - there are plenty to choose from here with lots of free options but I recommend using a paid service if possible (see section below)</li>
</ul>
<h3 style="font-weight: normal;">Using proxies</h3>
<p>You should always check how changing your IP influences the page. You may be surprised! On some websites it's important to check how changing your location affects the displayed result (can be fewer items, a redirect or simply getting blocked). For this, you can use several tools such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>A VPN browser extension, be careful though, some may have security issues such as leaking your IP, use a paid version if you can or be sure to use a safe free trial of a paid one</li>
<li>Setup a proxy in your machine: another viable option can be to set a proxy directly on your operating system. You could also use a VPN service that often comes with desktop apps</li>
</ul>
<p>If you have lots of extensions like me, you may wonder at some point, how these influence certain requests. You can check how your browser cache changes the loaded page (defaults, cookies, extensions, etc.) by opening the page in an incognito tab</p>
<p>Conversely, you can also enable any extension you need in incognito mode from the browser's extension settings.</p>
<h2>Postman, the REST client</h2>
<p>Sending requests is easy.</p>
<div><img src="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-63-AM.png" alt=""></div>
<p><span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://learning.postman.com/docs/postman/launching-postman/introduction/" style="color: #990100;">Postman's</a> </span>UI is pretty intuitive and has lots of features. You have the basic information about your request such as the URL, it's parameters, and headers to fill in. You can also enable or disable each of these as you like for testing.</p>
<p>You can of course send POST requests as wee using postman, the only difference is the request body which can be specified in the 'Body' tab where multiple formats are available.</p>
<div><img src="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hubfs/scraping%20tools%20article%20idea-Jul-03-2020-11-12-39-39-AM.png" alt=""></div>
<div> </div>
<div>Note that you can leave notes in the description column as additional information about certain parameters.</div>
<p><em>Tip: postman will save cookies from a response by default. You need to disable these yourself if you need to or change how cookies are handled in the 'General' section from settings which you can access in the top right by clicking on the wrench icon.</em></p>
<h3>Collections</h3>
<p>An awesome feature is the ability to store requests for later use, you can create a collection of requests. Just create a new collection and save the request there.</p>
<h3>With proxies</h3>
<p>It's also pretty straight forward to configure a proxy for postman. You can use the system settings or a specific proxy with or without login from the settings panel.</p>
<p>You can import curl requests into postman (such as those generated from a browser request as I mentioned before). This can save you lots of time by helping you quickly reproduce a request.</p>
<p>This can also be done the other way around: export your postman request for curl or python. By default, it will use the requests library so if you need it for <a href="https://scrapy.org/">Scrapy </a>you must change it a bit.</p>
<h2>Scrapy shell</h2>
<p>Sometimes you will need to code some logic to extract the data you need. Whether it is testing selectors or formatting data, Scrapy has you covered with the <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://docs.scrapy.org/en/latest/topics/shell.html" style="color: #990100;">Scrapy shell</a></span>. This is an interactive shell designed for testing extraction logic for web scraping but it works with python code as well.</p>
<p>You need to have Scrapy installed in your python environment:</p>
<p>$ pip install scrapy</p>
<p>Then you can simply run 'scrapy shell' to start it or you can add an URL as the first parameter and it will send a get request to that.</p>
<p>$ scrapy shell</p>
<p>$ scrapy shell <URL> # to start with a plain GET request</p>
<p><em>Tip: The default python shell that scrapy uses can be enhanced. If you install </em><span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://ipython.org/" style="color: #990100;">IPython </a></span><em>in your environment, Scrapy will detect it and use that as the shell which enables lots of useful features such as syntax highlighting and tab completion to name a few. (</em><span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://bpython-interpreter.org/" style="color: #990100;">bpython</a></span><em> is also supported)</em></p>
<p>You may now want to check the docs by typing shelp() which will display information about various available objects. One useful feature is the 'view' function which can be called with the response as parameter.</p>
<p>Once you are inside the shell, you can use 'fetch' to send a get request for a given url or directly fetch a scrapy request object (which you can later use in your spiders!):</p>
<pre><code class="language-python">fetch('')
# this is equivalent to:
from scrapy import Request
req = Request('')
fetch(req)
</code></pre>
<p>Since now you have access to a response object you can also test your selectors. This is a basic example of <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Selectors" style="color: #990100;">css </a></span>and <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/XPath" style="color: #990100;">xpath </a></span>selectors:</p>
<pre class="“language-python”"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier;"><div id="topping"></span><br><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier;"><p>Pineapple</p></span><br><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier;"></div></span><br><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier;"># css selector                                                                      
>>> response.css('div#topping p::text').get()
'Pineapple'
# xpath selector
>>> response.xpath('//div[@id="topping"]/p/text()').get()</span><br><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier;">'Pineapple'
</span><span style="background-color: transparent;"></span></pre>
<p><span style="background-color: transparent;">Note that the shell checks for a valid scrapy project in the current directory and makes use of this when sending requests or fetching project settings. This can be useful when you're trying to debug your middlewares!</span></p>
<p>Since the shell will use your project's settings it will also make use of existing middleware so you can use these to manage session, bans and more.</p>
<h2>Learn more about web scraping</h2>
<p>As you have seen, there are many useful tools that you can use to effectively extract data from the web. Some websites are easier than others, but leveraging these tools should make your life a little easier, even when dealing with complex websites. If you want to learn more about web scraping best practises and how to ensure you can extract data not just now but also in the long term, we have a free downloadable guide that could help you on your web data extraction journey.</p>

            xhr.open('POST', '/_hcms/perf', true /*async*/);
            xhr.setRequestHeader("Content-type", "application/json");
            xhr.onreadystatechange = function () {
                // do nothing.
            };
            var connection = navigator.connection || navigator.mozConnection || navigator.webkitConnection;
            function populateNetworkInfo(name, connection, info) {
                if (name in connection) {
                    info[name] = connection[name];
                }
            }
            var networkInfo = {};
            if (connection) {
                ['type', 'effectiveType', 'downlink', 'rtt'].forEach(function(name) {
                    populateNetworkInfo(name, connection, networkInfo);
                });
            }
            var perfData = {
                url: location.href,
                portal: 4367560,
                content: 31779772866,
                group: -1,
                connection: networkInfo,
                timing: performance.timing
            };
            xhr.send(JSON.stringify(perfData));
        }, 3000);  // Execute this 3 seconds after onload.
    });
})();
</script>

<!-- Save UTM for links to app.scrapinghub.com -->
<script>
function getQueryStrParam(name, url) {
    if (!url) url = window.location.search;
    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
        results = regex.exec(url);
    if (!results) return null;
    if (!results[2]) return '';
    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
}

function storeUrlParam(param_name, url) {
    var hasCookie = getStoredParam(param_name);
    if (hasCookie == "" || hasCookie) return;
    var param = getQueryStrParam(param_name, url) || "";
    Cookies.set(param_name, param, {
        domain: ".scrapinghub.com",
        expires: 90
    })
}

function getStoredParam(param_name) {
    return Cookies.get(param_name, {
        domain: ".scrapinghub.com"
    })
}

function isPlatformLink(dest_url) {
    return (
        dest_url.startsWith("https://app.scrapinghub.com") ||
        dest_url.startsWith("http://app.scrapinghub.com") ||
        dest_url.startsWith("app.scrapinghub.com")
    )
}

jQuery(function ($) {
    $(document).on('click', 'a[cta_dest_link]', function(e) {
        const dest_url = $(e.currentTarget).attr("cta_dest_link");
        if ( dest_url && isPlatformLink(dest_url)) {
            storeUrlParam("utm_campaign", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_activity", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_medium", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_source", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_content", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_primary", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_secondary", dest_url);
            storeUrlParam("utm_goal", dest_url);
        }
    }); 
});
</script>

            <div class="post-page-content"> 
             
             <div class="hs-featured-image-wrapper">
               <a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/job-postings-api-stable-release" title="" class="hs-featured-image-link">
                 <img src="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/hubfs/Job-Postings-Beta-API-Extract-Job-Postings-at-Scale-with-our-Newest-API-BLOG-v2.gif" class="hs-featured-image" alt="">
               </a>

                <div class="section post-header">
                  <h1><span id="hs_cos_wrapper_name" class="hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_text" style="" data-hs-cos-general-type="meta_field" data-hs-cos-type="text">Job Postings API: Stable release</span></h1>
                  <div class="byline">
                    <span class="date">
                      <i class="fa fa-calendar-o"></i>
                      <a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/job-postings-api-stable-release">July 09, 2020 </a>
                    </span>
                    <span class="author">
                      <i class="fa fa-user"></i>
                      <a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/author/john-campbell">John Campbell</a>	
                    </span>
                    <span class="custom_listing_comments">
                      <i class="fa fa-comments-o"></i>
                      
                      
                      <a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/job-postings-api-stable-release#comments-listing">0 Comments</a>
                    </span>
                  </div>
             </div>
                
                <div class="section post-body">
                  <span id="hs_cos_wrapper_post_body" class="hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_rich_text" style="" data-hs-cos-general-type="meta_field" data-hs-cos-type="rich_text"><h2 style="text-align: center;">Hassle-Free, Structured, Machine-Readable<br>Job Postings Data </h2>
<p>We are excited to announce our newest data extraction API. The <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://scrapinghub.com/data-api-job-postings/?utm_campaign=AJP&utm_activity=BLO&utm_medium=ORG&utm_source=HUB&utm_content=BLP&utm_primary=AEX&utm_goal=FTR" style="color: #990100;">Job Postings API</a></span> is now out of BETA and publicly available as a stable release. </p>
<!--more-->
<p>If you are ready to roll up your sleeves and get started, here are the links you need:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://www.scrapinghub.com/data-api-job-postings?utm_campaign=AJP&utm_activity=BLO&utm_medium=ORG&utm_source=HUB&utm_content=BLP&utm_primary=AEX&utm_goal=FTR" style="color: #990100;">Get the Job Postings API</a></span></li>
<li><span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://doc.scrapinghub.com/autoextract/job_posting.html?utm_campaign=AJP&utm_activity=BLO&utm_medium=ORG&utm_source=HUB&utm_content=BLP&utm_primary=AEX&utm_goal=FTR" style="color: #990100;">AutoExtract - Job Postings API Documentation</a></span></li>
</ul>
<p>While this blog covers most of the notable improvements & extensive testing that the API has undergone, that warrants an exit from Beta, together with some high-level uses; it’s important to remember that we have already covered it <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://blog.scrapinghub.com/job-postings-at-scale-beta-api" style="color: #990100;">extensively before</a></span>.</p>
<h2>What Has The Stable Release Of Job Posting API Solved</h2>
<p>We are moving AutoExtract Job Postings out of beta after making substantial <strong>improvements in downloading quality</strong>, completely eliminating several classes of errors, and making <strong>improvements in extraction quality</strong>. Aggregator websites where the API had a tendency to return failed requests on the BETA release have now been addressed, paving the way for widespread use.</p>
<p>These changes were released to production as part of 20.5.0</p>
<h2>Unleash Insights & Drive Business Intelligence (BI) With Job Posting Data</h2>
<p>If you are looking to discern insights on the activities of organisations of all sizes, from start-ups to Fortune 100 companies, job postings can provide context for analysts to understand the market landscape. Where and how are competitors, suppliers and customers or even the industry, in general, structuring their business. Which technologies they are investing in, which ones they are no longer actively pursuing, what key markets are they pushing into, amongst other things.</p>
<h3>Technology Buying Signals Derived From Job Postings: A Glimpse Into A Job Posting Data BI Use Case</h3>
<p>The technology stack of a start-up can (and should) look extremely different from that of a Fortune 1000 company. As organisations grow and evolve, expanding their workforce is a must to answer the on-going demands of the marketplace proactively. This is true to all sectors and industries but especially so in the context of the information technology industry, with so many roles and disciplines that need to be filled amid an ever-changing landscape.</p>
<p>Imagine this scenario - an aspiring organisation within the Information Technology (IT) industry wants to expand into new markets. To do this, they need to recruit for a plethora of roles. From hiring cybersecurity professionals to either provide InfoSec support or man the Security Operations Centres (SOC), to  DevOps/IT teams will be needed to deploy & maintain what the software engineers have developed; someone will have to project manage and someone needs to do the administrative heavy lifting. </p>
<p>IT is a competitive market to be in, and surely enough competitors are racing to have a head start. Within this context, business intelligence is paramount to gauge whether our fictitious organisations’ plans are worthwhile in the first place or not. To accomplish this, their insights function needs to understand the recruitment practices of their top 10 competitors that operate a global workforce and have job listings in 100 different countries and 10 different languages - that is 10 x 100 = 1K websites to constantly monitor. With traditional manual scraping techniques, this will amount to a multi-man year-long project.  With Scrapinghub’s <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://scrapinghub.com/data-api-job-postings/?utm_campaign=AJP&utm_activity=BLO&utm_medium=ORG&utm_source=HUB&utm_content=BLP&utm_primary=AEX&utm_goal=FTR" style="color: #990100;">Job Postings API</a></span>, a steady always-on reliable steam of data into our organisation’s data warehouse and BI platform can be set up in a matter of days/hours/minutes.</p>
<h3>Master Data Management For The Recruitment Industry</h3>
<p>Our AutoExtract Job Postings API is tailor-made to answer the demands of the recruitment industry, particularly if data synchronisation between job boards or job aggregators and the individual recruitment agencies databases where uniformity, accuracy, semantic consistency and <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://status.scrapinghub.com/" style="color: #990100;">always-on</a></span> reliability is an operational must.</p>
<h2>Get Machine-Readable, Structured Job Data Without Code!</h2>
<p>Without our Job Postings API, you would need to write custom code for each job posting page to extract and parse the data. On top of that, you would also have the maintenance overhead and all the troubleshooting that comes with it. </p>
<p><strong>Our API allows you to focus on the data, not harvesting it!</strong></p>
<p>We are continuously improving the underlying machine learning technology, so you can be assured you get the highest quality job data possible.<code><br></code></p>
<h2>How To Use It?</h2>
<p>Using the API is simple:</p>
<ol>
<li>First, provide a feed or the URLs you want to extract job posting data from into AutoExtract.</li>
<li>Get a coffee (or whatever is your drink of choice), lay back and let the API do its magic! </li>
<li>Voilà; structured, machine-readable job posting data directly into your environment in JSON.</li>
</ol>
<pre><code class="language-json">[{
    "job_posting": {
      "title": "Regional Manager",
      "datePosted": "2019-06-19T00:00:00",
      "validThrough": "2019-08-19T00:00:00",
      "description": "Job Description ...",
      "descriptionHtml": "HTML for Job Description ...",
      "baseSalary": {
        "raw": "Competitive pay based on qualifications and experience"
      },
      "jobLocation": {
        "raw": "North Pole"
      },
      "hiringOrganization": {
        "raw": "ACME Corporation"
      },
      "employmentType": "Full-time",
      "probability": 0.95,
      "url": "https://example.com/job"
    },
    "query": {
      "id": "1564747029122-9e02a1868d70b7a3",
      "domain": "example.com",
      "userQuery": {
        "pageTypeHint": "jobPosting",
        "url": "https://example.com/job"
      }
    }
  }
 ]
</code></pre>
<p><a href="https://doc.scrapinghub.com/autoextract/job_posting.html?utm_campaign=AJP&utm_activity=BLO&utm_medium=ORG&utm_source=HUB&utm_content=BLP&utm_primary=AEX&utm_goal=FTR" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="color: #990100;">Learn more about the API in the documentation.</span></a></p>
<h2>Job Postings Data At Your Disposal</h2>
<p>Our Job Posting data API is ideal for</p>
<ul>
<li>Business intelligence</li>
<li>Business development</li>
<li>Job boards</li>
<li>Headhunting & recruitment agencies</li>
<li>Market research</li>
</ul>
<p>Some of the data fields you get in your API:</p>
<ul>
<li>Job title</li>
<li>Job description</li>
<li>Date published</li>
</ul>
<h2><strong>Try The Job Postings API Today!</strong></h2>
<p>Here’s what you need to do if you want to get access to Job Postings API:</p>
<ol>
<li>Sign up for a free trial <span style="color: #990100;"><a href="https://scrapinghub.com/data-api-job-postings/?utm_campaign=AJP&utm_activity=BLO&utm_medium=ORG&utm_source=HUB&utm_content=BLP&utm_primary=AEX&utm_goal=FTR" style="color: #990100;">here</a></span>.</li>
<li>You can start using the Job Postings API straight away.</li>
<li>You will not be charged for any Job Posting API usage during your trial. </li>
</ol>
<p>If you want to check out any of our other AutoExtract APIs, <a href="https://www.scrapinghub.com/automatic-data-extraction-api"><span style="color: #990100;">check them out here for free</span>!</a></p>
<p>PS: I would appreciate it if you let us know what you think of our new API in the comments.</p></span>
                  <div class="share-it">
                    <h3 class="sd-title">Share this:</h3>
                    <span id="hs_cos_wrapper_blog_social_sharing" class="hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_widget hs_cos_wrapper_type_blog_social_sharing" style="" data-hs-cos-general-type="widget" data-hs-cos-type="blog_social_sharing">
<div class="hs-blog-social-share">
